bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to William A. Wood, February 1, 1950

div1.p: Hench provides biographical information about some of the men involved with the yellow fever experiments. He stresses the importance of celebrating the 50th anniversary of Reed's work.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to William A. Wood, February 1, 1950
div1.opener:
Y f
February 1, 1950
Mr. William A. Wood
Division of Public Liaison
State Department
Washington, D. C.
My dear Mr. Wood:
div1.p:
Until now I was unable to find the address of Mr. John L. Hanberry.
His address is 61 Summers Avenue, Orangeburg, South Carolina.

As I told you, the five men still living who had some chief con-
cern with the conquest of yellow fever and the work of Walter Reed and his
associates are as follows: Mr. John Moran, Calle 25 #804, entre B y C,
Apartment 3, Vedado, Havana, Cuba; Mr. James Hanberry, address above; Dr.
Robert Cooke, Lexington-Rockbridge Health Department, Lexington, Virginia;
General Jefferson R. Kean, 2804 N Street, N. S., Georgetown, Washington, D. C.;
General Albert E. Truby, 145 Laurel Street, San Francisco, California.

Mr. Moran was one of the first to volunteer to Walter Reed for the
experiments and he was given experimental yellow fever. He is a very articu-
late man and was for years manager of the Sun Oil Company in Cuba. He is now
retired. He has an ulcer and I am sure will not leave Cuba unless his wife
comes along.

Last year he was invited to some affair in Washington, an interna-
tional public health congress. He was invited with expenses for himself
alone but since he is on a small annuity he could not afford to pay his
wife's expenses and therefore declined. I think I was the only one that know
why he declined. If they had paid his wife's expenses also so that she
could look after him and look after his diet, he probably would have come.
In my opinion he is by far the best one. Although he speaks very ably in
conversation, he pretends to be shy on his feet. On the occasion, three
of four years ago, when he was being honored at the University of Virginia,
he was asked to speak. He got up and made a few stammering remarks and then
suggested that they merely ask him questions and he became quite articulate
and most interesting. Therefore, if he had a script to read from I am sure
he would do well. He is deserving of much consideration and honor.

Mr. Hanberry was also a volunteer and deserving of much credit.
However, he is not as intelligent a man as Mr. Moran by any means and in-
cidentally deserted from the Army but all was forgiven and he later received
the special Congressional Medal. As I told you, I think he is a little more
pleased by attention than Mr. Moran. He would be satisfactory but not as
satisfactory as Moran.

Dr. Robert Cooke accepted part of the experiments. He lived in little
Building No. 1, the filth room but did not accept experimental yellow fever.
When I visited him a few years ago I found his memory very poor.
A C
Va
Mr. William A. Wood
- 2 -
February 1, 1950
If someone wrote a script for him he would undoubtedly read it off but I
don't believe he could help much without the script.

These three are the only actual surviving participants of the
experiments. General Kean was Walter Reed's right hand man and superior
officer in Cuba. He was the surgeon for the area in which Walter Reed
did the work. He is one of the most intelligent and intellectual men I have
ever met and his memory is excellent; however he is around 90 years of age and
has a bum knee. He was Deputy Surgeon General bears ago. He has been my
prime source of knowledge and is more or less the final authority in matters
concerning Walter Reed and the conquest of yellow fever. Whether or not he
would be willing to go to New York for such a program, I do not know but he
knows more about the affair than anybody else, including the survivors.

General Albert E. Truby was a young lieutenant and was temporary
commanding officer of the hospital in Cuba where Walter Reed did his work.
Four or five years ago he wrote a book on the subject, a very good one. Next
to General Kean he knows most about the affair but was not a participant.
He had a slight stroke three years ago but has recovered with a slight limp
and does, on occasion, travel east.

The finances of all of these men are such that they would have to
have their expenses paid. You know the average pension for a retired
officer.

Walter Reed's son, daughter and widow are still living. His son
is a very able man who became major general during the last war and held
several very responsible positions. He is living in Washington, General
Walter Lawrence Reed, 2810 Thirty-Sixth Place, N. W. He was a young
lieutenant in Cuba at the time but was not stationed in Havana and although
he knows a great deal about his father's work, it was largely through
hearsay. He would be a highly acceptable participant in the program, should
you wish a representative of the Reed family. Walter Reed's widow is over
90 and hopelessly ill in Blue Ridge Summit, Pennsylvania, under the care of
her daughter, Mrs. Blossom Reed. I think that about covers the situation.

It is extremely appropriate that “WE, THE PEOPLE” put on this
program this year as 1950 is the 50th anniversary of the work of Walter
Reed. They may or may not realize this. I hope you will bring this to
their attention as it will make it especially appropriate and give a time-
liness to the occasion.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
